sp.p:
I look at a landscape I cannot
help seeing all its defects. It is fortunate for us, however, that Nature is so
imperfect, as otherwise we should
have had no art at all. Art is our spirited
protest, our gallant attempt to teach Nature
her proper place. As for the infinite
variety of Nature, that is a pure
myth.Schroeder argues that this is both a challenging of John Addington Symonds 1887 assertion that "t will never match the infinite variety and subtlety of nature; no drawing or painting will equal the primary beauties of the living model' (The Model', Fortnightly Review , vol.42, (Dec. 1887), p 859) and an allusiton to Shakespeare's Antony and Cleopatra, II.ii.239 f. It is not to be found in
Nature herself . It resides in the imagination,
or fancy, or cultivated blindness of the man who
looks at her.

Cyril. Well, you need not look at
the landscape. You can lie on
the grass and smoke and talk.

Vivian. But Nature is so uncomfortable.
Grass is hard and lumpy and damp,
and full of dreadful black insects. Why, even Large commercial furniture firm, located at Tottenham Court Road.
Morris'Guy identifies the reference as an allusion to "the simple, inexpensive, black-stained rush-bottomed 'Sussex' chairs" sold by Morris & Co., "a firm established by poet, painter, and designer William Morris" (362). poorest workman could make you a more comfortable
seat than the whole of Nature can. Nature pales before the furniture of "the street which from Oxford has borrowed its name,‚Äù as the poet you love so much once vilely phrased it.The addition I
don't complain. If Nature had been comfortable, mankind would never have
invented architecture, and I prefer houses to the open air. In a house
we all feel of the proper proportions.
Everything is subordinated to us,
fashioned for our use and our pleasure.
